comments.commentBody: Chris, You are a bit confused.  It was Israel that was attacked repeatedly by its Arab neighbors.  This began in 1948 when Israel was attacked by the armies of 5 Arab nations.  And please present evidence that Israel got its nuclear weapons by stealing plans from the US.  Israel has more Nobel prize winners in Physics per capita than any other country on earth.  Do you really think it needed to steal ideas?
I certainly witness anger, but the vast majority of people supporting Palestine know that millions of decent Jewish people want no part of Bibi's games and lies.

To 'gensleuth'
"Americans also developed a Christian theology to explain why black Africans should be enslaved by white people."

If I understand my history correctly, it was the Church of England, after a long drawn out examination of Africans anatomy, that decided that they were more closely related to primates than humans. That is when the slave trade really grew.

The church's clerics decision may have been influenced by the wealthy aristocrats who wanted in on this new lucrative revenue stream. We live with this same dehumanization every day even after hundreds of years.

While Netanyahu continues to practice the lowest level of real politic. I don't understand how anything has changed. The Palestinians still have no power to force negotiations. The current administration's days are numbered and Hillary Clinton will certainly disavow any changes in US policy that come remotely close to isolating Israel. Finally, Israel still has a stronger, more advance, more nuclear-armed military than the rest of the region combined. A force that will continue to be maintained at a cost of 3 billion dollars a year to the American taxpayers

Netanyahu doesn't care what Obama thinks. If he wins the election, he's untouchable. That's the truth. No matter how infuriating.

Yes they do--his tactics; yes they have--deepened my anger. Netanyahu is a republican in training. Coming to the US to insult Obama was a major tactical error; using the term "Arab" in a way that is no different than our American "n-word" is a disgrace to any and all who do not support that usage. A horror amongst many in the nationalist fever (and I do mean fever), is framing all non-Jews in Israel "proper" and the occupied territories as "Arabs", a very bad word. There are Arab Muslims, Arab Christians, non-Arab Christians, non-Arab Muslims who have lived there for much longer than the Euro-and American-Jews who claim it as their own.

The Obama administration should no longer play touchy-feely with this Israeli so-called government. Netanyahu is a "tin-pot dictator" in waiting. His nationalism, his government, his seething lies. No Palestinian state, maybe Palestinian state, what Palestinian state? He says he speaks for all Jews. He doesn't. But what can Jews of the diaspora do? Lobby their respective governments to withhold and withdraw support of the neo-fascist Israel. This man, Netanyahu, is making the planet Earth less safe for everyone, not just Jews. And let's remember, he is sitting on nuclear weapons himself.

Netanyahu does not speak for me. He is a despicable man who has learned well from his republican trainers to play to his benefactors. He says, "All Jews should move to Israel." Where, I ask, is that place? Certainly not in its current location.
They look really cool to me. Sometimes a shoe is just a shoe.
Whatever happened to "All the news that's fit to print"?

Really?
This is content?
Oh, sorry. I guess it is marketing...
How could I be so foolish.
And NYT will help in the promo.

The problem with this whole athletic shoe business is that it is using NCAA basketball to sell high-priced shoes to young people most of whom really can't afford them. The NCAA should ban such exploitative marketing using its teams.
Eleanor Roosevelt.

We are deluged with ads for no- name colleges often with "patriotic" names offering some sort of education for potential low-wage jobs that can't possibly require a college degree in the traditional sense. What possible type of "college education" is required to qualify the student for what is a thinly diguised low wage security job ("jobs in CSI and law enforcement"). Another massive fraud on both the student and taxpayers to fatten the "private colleges" so favored by the republicans.
Went I graduated from Notre Dame, a real university, in 73 with a BA in History and no student debt, due to lw tuition, partial scholarship and working in 2 campus cafeterias. Unlike the student palaces today, our dorm was built in 1927 and had the lustre of a military barrack. But I received a 1st rate education and a sense if civic and moral obligation that stayed with me through life. Btw, ND never had "fraternities" which we considered inane and contempible at other schools.
I haven't seen Antisemitic comments here, and to continually talk about the Holocaust in a discussion about Palestine shows that Palestine is paying the price for the Nazi horrors.
Where will the Palestinians go?

I am not Jewish, but I grew up in Jewish neighborhoods and felt a strong affection for Israel as a haven after the Holocaust. That has eroded with the settlements and general rightward swing of the government. However, nothing before has angered me as much as Netanyahu's speech, which I took as an inappropriate interference with America's affairs.

I feel that the U.S., in the past, has often supported Israel to the detriment of our own interests. Now that Netanyahu has shown contempt for our President and Secretary of State, it's time for us to rethink our automatic support of Israel at the U.N. and internationally.

In politics the only fatal mistake is not to recognize friends from foes. Netanyahu made his choice explicit when he spoke at Capitol Hill against President Obama's Middle East foreign policy. As long as Israel support in Congress is kept intact, Netanyahu's political life will go on tranquil.

In fairness many Jewish people work tirelessly for justice for the Palestinians, but this is the first time I have liked so many comments on NYT.  It's an emotional time as millions more see what was hidden or not believed.  we may hope now.

I worked for a couple of years as a drug rep on the south side of Chicago. Major portions of the patient population were medically under served and many fell in to the gaps in Medicaid and other assistance. It was illegal to give expired samples to a physician but there was one doctor in particular that let all the drug reps know to bring him short-dated samples prior to expiration. This doctor knew what we all knew, these valuable drugs are in 99.9% of cases good for a year at least following expiration date. So rather than shipping samples back to the company to be destroyed, this doctor worked with reps to make sure that he signed for them, legally, pre-expiration and then would distribute them in his indigent care clinic. A few such grass roots efforts like this existed in my area. I knew very well that most of the doctors I worked with would not just give a couple of samples to get a patient started. They would prescribe the medications for those who had a means of covering the cost. For patients with no assistance they would give them a lunch bag of samples to get through the month. If the medication worked they would get a bag the next month and so on.

Everyone is so ready to believe drug companies are only trying to make billions off people's ill health. And, yes you can look at it in those terms. But being on the front line working with the doctors I can tell you that one doctor's informal work with reps helped real live people in need right when the needed it.

The reason it's more violent and unstable is because of the rank injustice.  Unless of course you think Palestinians should roll over and die or freeze to death etc.  There are endless ways to die unnaturally in Palestine at the hands of Israel.

They are called color commentary stories and as one who isn't following every single team, I found it an interesting one.  Plenty of other space here for hardcore basketball coverage, so it is not as if this story bumped one more worthy in your eyes of coverage.
What a waste of space! Is the NYT NCAAM coverage is so saturated that you have nothing better left to offer us than this nonsense?

Re: "There is no aggregate demand because consumers are broke."
Agreed...disagree with your characterization of the Seventies, however.
Consumers were broke back then, also.
I know I was broke and I know most of my friends were basically broke.
Credit cards were highly uncommon in my crowd, though, based upon my recollection. So, although we were broke, at least we were not in debt to a significant degree. Maybe you owed a buddy ten bucks or whatever, but that was about the extent of the typical credit line in my economic circle.

Consumption theory. Don't you think that most economists ignore wealth accumulation in everything they do?

For instance, the idea of marginal income taxation makes sense when discussing most of us, as we have little to no net worth that we can readily convert to fuel our consumption (or to finance a different asset/Investment and its flow of earnings to the income side). People of high net worth in fact have all their new income as being on the margin as they can readily convert net worth to consumption, unlike most of us.

If we had a net worth tax, most of us would check off one of the boxes showing our net worth in a range from negative to some threshold number to exclude basic saving needs), and we'd pay income taxes like we do now. Others who check off one of the high net worth boxes would pull up income tax rates on almost all income, with rates progressing downward to the basic threshold, because they have net worth conversion capacity making all new income on the margin, so to speak. Change to this view of consumption and perhaps you don't need a net worth tax to lower burdens on most people's consumption in a 12-month period, where most taxes lay.

So ignoring net worth is used to govt finance and economic policies that end up with higher tax burdens on the bulk of us who only have income, most of which needs to be consumed.

Time to attack the age of frozen certainties.

Start with the theory of consumption. Marginal propensity to consume on income that is realistically expected involves short term income. The idea that a individual's marginal propensity to consume is determined by both current income and windfall income, or on "income smoothing" (whatever that is) is wrong.

No decides to buy or not to buy a BMW based on his or her analysis of projected lifetime income. He is making a certain income; he makes the decision.

As an individual becomes more successful, his purchases decline because he has less opportunity. In short, he has acquired much of what he wants and needs.

As for stagflation, oil prices quintupled and did so at a time when the bills for Viet Nam were coming due.

The rocket was going up. Oil prices increased 100% per year, faster than we could throw water on it, but government from 1973 to 1979, did nothing to try to stop it.

That is, there was no economic reaction to the supply shock. Consequently, there was no normal Phillips curve response.

In reality, no one was fighting inflation at all. Merely buttons that said "WIN" (Whip Inflation Now.) Please.

The economists who held those positions on both consumption and inflation were wrong then and they are wrong now.

There will be no inflation in the near term because there is no aggregate demand.

There is no aggregate demand because consumers are broke.

Like Elvis, the money has left the building.
Proud, really?
And this is a big, big part of the problem.
Israel is now experiencing the brunt of liberal wrath.

Commenting from Aventura Florida, home to a large, diverse and wonderful Jewish population from all over the Country, I have to say about 80% of those I and others have spoken to and with  strongly support Bibi. Even Debbie Wasserman Schultz attended his congressional speech with utmost vigor. We are not appalled by Mr. Netanyahu's behavior.....we are proud. Immensely Proud!
Hoosier daddy?

So the wine makers are responsible for the way Netanyahu talks?? As a general rule citizens of a country are not responsible for their leaders actions. After weren't we all American citizens when Bush lied to the world and destroyed Iraq.

Please name one "democratic secular state" in the Middle East.  Syria?  Ha ha. Iraq--falling into tribalism.  Lebanon?  Divided between Christian enclaves, Shia and Shiites.  Israel is not racist, it is the state of the Jewish people, in the same way France is the state of the French people and Poland is the state of the Polish people.  Your solution of a democratic secular state is a hallucination.
Harriett Tubman, an abolitionist, Union spy, and fearless warrior and speaker.
